titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Paltsits Collection--Ulster County, New York
1643-1829
MS 477
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Jan Hilley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-02T16:08-0400

did.unittitle: Paltsits Collection--Ulster County, New York
did.abstract: A collection of 114 items relating to the history of Ulster County, New York, in particular land transactions, legal papers and church records. All were collected by Dr. V.H. Paltsits.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Photocopying undertaken by staff only. Limited to twenty exposures of stable, unbound material per day. (Researchers may not accrue unused copy amounts from previous days.)

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to quote from this collection in a publication must be requested and granted in writing. Send permission requests, citing the name of the collection from which you wish to quote, to
Library Director
The New-York Historical Society
170 Central Park West
New York, NY 10024

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: This collection should be cited as the Paltsits Ulster County Collection, MS 477, the New-York Historical Society.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Ulster County, in southeastern New York State, is bordered by the Hudson River to the east and the Catskill Mountains to the northwest. Its early inhabitants were Algonquian-speaking Indians, such as the Delaware.

chronitem.event: Early adventurers came into Ulster County area to trade with the Indians for corn and pelts.
Fur-trading post established on the future site of Kingston.
Handful of settlers from Holland moved down from near Albany.

Land purchased from the Esopus, a tribe of the Delaware Nation, for farming. Built village called Esopus, later Wiltwyck (Dutch for "wild woods"). After skirmishes with Indians, Peter Stuyvesant, Governor of the Dutch colony, brought soldiers up and built a stockade.
Wiltwyck, now part of the English colony, was renamed Kingston.
French Huguenots, under the leadership of Louis Dubois, founded settlement of New Paltz on 36,000 acres of land purchased from the Indians and patented to them by Governor Edmund Andros.

Ulster, one of the original New York counties, was chartered to "contain the towns of Kingston, Hurley, and Marbletown, Foxhall and New Paltz, and all the villages, neighborhoods, and Christian inhabitations on the west side of the Hudson River, from the Murderers Creek, near the Highlands, to the Sawyers' Creek." Named for the traditional Irish province of Ulster, then under the control of James, Duke of York and Albany (later King James II).

Kingston, the county seat, was the first capital of New York State. The state's first legislature, senate and supreme court convened in Kingston and George Clinton was inaugurated there as New York's first governor. In late 1777, British troops entered and burned Kingston, destroying much of the town.
The community survived and Kingston incorporated as a village.
Delaware and Hudson Canal completed. Kingston was the eastern terminus.

bioghist.p: Source of Information: French, J.H. The Historical and Statistical Gazetteer of New York State. Syracuse, N.Y.: R.P. Smith, 1860.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Paltsits Ulster County Collection is made up of a wide variety of materials related to the history of Ulster County, New York. All items were collected by Dr. Victor Hugo Paltsits (1867-1952), an archivist and librarian who was, at one time, head of the Manuscripts Division of the New York Public Library.

Materials within the collection date from the mid-seventeenth through the early nineteenth century. Examples include deeds and other land papers, surveys, court documents, notes, accounts, meeting and court minutes, petitions, reports, maps, receipts, letters, church pledges, marriage records, election tallies and genealogical notes. A large portion of the collection relates to property transactions. Activities of the Dutch Reformed Church are also prominent. In addition to church financing and construction papers, there are also items that relate to the split within the Church (1754-1771) between the Coetus Party (mostly American-born members who favored independence from Amsterdam) and the Conferentie Party (mostly immigrants from the Netherlands who sought to maintain the status quo).

Many of the documents are written in Dutch. The condition of materials in this collection is mixed. Quite a number of items are fragile, while others are in fair to good condition. There are several oversized items in Box 2.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged following the sequence of an item-level inventory created by Dr. Paltsits. For the most part, the items are in a chronological sequence. Copies of Dr. Paltsits' handwritten notes, included within the folders, provide supplemental information and estimated time frames for many of the undated items.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material at The New-York Historical Society
relatedmaterial.p: The New-York Historical Society has a significant amount of material related to the early history of Ulster County. Within the Manuscript Department, for example, is another collection of various property records, court documents, correspondence and financial papers - the Ulster County Collection (Call Phrase: Ulster County). There are also individual manuscript items such as the following:

list.item: Land Surveys, 1767-[176?] Call Phrase: BV Gale, Samuel
Patent, 1719/20, March 17, Ulster County (N.Y.) Call Phrase: Y1720

relatedmaterial.p: The Library contains a number of related volumes such as the following:

list.item: Clearwater, Alphonso T., ed., The History of Ulster County, New York. Kingston, NY: W.J. Van Deusen, 1907. (Call Number: F127.U4 C6)

DeWitt, Deweese W. Ulster County's Reformed Church Legacy: a Record of All Dutch Reformed Churches Whose Origin Came from Ulster County, New York. Kingston, N.Y.: Old Dutch Men's Club, Old Dutch Church, 1977. (Call Number: F127.U4D52)
Fried, Marc B., The Early History of Kingston and Ulster County, N.Y. Marbletown, NY: Ulster County Historical Society [1975]. (Call Number: F129.K5 F82)

Sylvester, Nathaniel Bartlett, History of Ulster County, New York: With Illustrations and Biographical Sketches of its Prominent Men and Pioneers. Philadelphia: Everts & Peck, 1880 (Philadelphia: Press of J.B. Lippincott & Co.). (Call Number: F127.U4 S95)
Ulster County Historical Society, Kingston, N.Y., Collections of the Ulster Historical Society, Volume I. Kingston, Hommel & Lounsbery, printers [etc.] 1860-62. (Call Number: F127.U4 U4)
Van Buren, Augustus H., A History of Ulster County Under the Dominion of the Dutch. Kingston, NY: [s.n.], 1923.

Calendar of Documents
#1 Data relating to the Pioneers of Catskill, N.Y. (1 p.)
#2 Accounts of a brewer in Esopus [Kingston], N.Y. (2 pp.)
#3 The debit of Jacob Barentsen [Barensane] as decreed before the court in Wiltwyck (1 p.)
#4 Transcript of Latin diploma awarded as Doctor in Medicine to Laurence Van Gaasbeeck (2 pp.)
#5 Marriage bond between Thomas Garton and Ann Nottingham, Marbletown, N.Y. (2 pp.)
#6 Minutes, Court of Sessions, Ulster County (8 pp.)
#7 Petition of Jacob Gouertle (?), Esopus, N.Y. to Gov. Thomas Dongan for authority to purchase land from the Indians (1 p.)
#8 Deed of Esopus Indians to Hendrickus Beekman (3 pp.)
#9 Brief of James Graham to the Ulster County Court of Oyer and Terminer on behalf of the patent rights of James II against Jacob Browne for trespass on the royal domain called "Shawangang." (1 p.)
#10A Obligations of indebtedness to the Dutch Church, Kingston, from Hendrick Aertse (1 p.)
#10B The same from Wesel ten Broeck (1 p.)
#10C Leaves from the Deacons' Book, Kingston (?) (2 pp.)
#11A Sums owed to the Deacons' Fund of the Dutch Church, Kingston (2 pp.)
#11B Annulment of Wesel ten Broeck's Pledge with interest (1 p.)
#12 Petition from Gartrite Bowne to Gov. Benjamin Fletcher re: her land dispute with John Camp (1 p.)
#13A Petition from Gertrick Browne to Gov. Fletcher re: her land on the Plate Creek (1 p.)
#13B Council minute; minute of the meeting of the Justices at Kingston (1 p.)

#14 Warrant from Gov. Fletcher to the Surveyor General of N.Y., for laying out grants in Ulster County for John Van Camp, Gerard, Jacob, and Cornelius Brewerton; John Everston and William Johnson (1 p.)
#15 Report of the Surveyor-General on the land in dispute between Gertuijcht Bruijn and John Van Camp, et. al. (1 p.)
#16 Deposition of Cornelius Cole re land dispute between Gertriet Brown and John Van Camp, et. al. (1 p.)
#17 Minutes of a Meeting of the Justices at Kingston hearing Indian testimony in Brown vs. Van Camp (1 p.)
#18A Minutes of the Provincial Council of New York held at Ft. William Henry to Adjudicate the dispute between Gertruy Bruiyn and John Van Camp et. al. (1 p.)
#18B Map of the land in dispute (1 p.)
#19 Quit Rent receipt from Thomas (?) Noxon to Soveryen Ten Hout, Kingston (1 p.)
#20 Accounts for use of the poor, New Paltz (?) (7 pp.)
#21 List of persons and amounts paid by them for letters patent of the town of Marbletown (fragment)
#22 Letters patent to Col. Henry Beekman, Capt. Thomas Garton and Capt. Charles Brodhead for the freeholders of Marbletown (6 pp.)
#23 Deacons' Poor Fund of Dutch Church of Kingston (4 pp.)
#24 Articles of Agreement between David Dubois and Hendrick Janse Cartwright (1 p.)
#25 Acknowledgement of Domine Johannes Petrus Nucella to the Consistory of Kingston that he has been fully paid
#26 Salary pledges made for the Domine, Ulster County (8 pp.)

#28 Record of Accounts due to Domine Petrus Vas, Kingston (2 pp.)

#30 ALS Johannes Janson, New York, to Capt. Egbert Schoonmaker (2 pp.)
#31 Release from Quit rent, and partition, from Col Jacob Rutson, Thomas Jansen, Martin Bogard, Angeltie Mowrets, and Rachael Bogard to William Nottingham (1 p.)
#32 Minutes, Ulster County Court of Sessions, regarding pay for services by the militia on the frontiers (4 pp.)
#33 Expenses for travel through Connecticut and Rhode Island (3 pp.)
#34 ALS William Nottingham to Thomas Sanders (1 p.)
#35 Letters of Administration under the will and probate of Johannes Westbrook (1 p.)
#36 Receipt from Daniel Brodhead to Jacobus Brujn for a lawyer's fee

#42 ALS Johannis Jansen to Augustus Jay (2 pp.)

#69B ALS Gerretje Ten Broeck to her sister (?) apparently telling of British raids in the Highlands (fragments)

#106 Birth, marriage and death records, Kingston (fragment)

#108 DS Robert R. Livingston and George Clinton: "Concluding Argument on part of the Plaintiffs in the Case of the Trustees of the Freeholders and Commonalty of the Town of Kingston against George Atkins and Johannis Hardenbergh," (15 pp.)
#109A Draft of a petition to the Legislature for David Hasbrouck, et. al., for allocation in a road near New Paltz (1 p.)
